label: Married
evidence: Martin Luther and Katharina von Bora were married on June 13, 1525, in Wittenberg. Johannes Bugenhagen performed the ceremony. The marriage produced six children.

label: Great-uncle
evidence: Reuchlin was Melanchthon's great-uncle. He supported young Melanchthon's education and gave him the Greek surname 'Melanchthon.'

label: Father-in-law
evidence: Rudolf Gwalther married Zwingli's daughter Regula, making him Zwingli's son-in-law.

label: Cousins
evidence: Calvin and Olivétan were cousins. Olivétan may have introduced Calvin to Reformed ideas. Calvin wrote the Latin preface to Olivétan's 1535 French Bible.

label: Married
evidence: Katharina married priest Matthew Zell in 1523, one of the first clerical marriages in Strasbourg.

label: Married
evidence: Marie Dentière married Antoine Froment, fellow Geneva reformer, after the death of her first husband.

label: Brothers
evidence: John the Steadfast was Frederick the Wise's brother and successor as Elector of Saxony.

label: Father and son
evidence: John Frederick I was the son and successor of John the Steadfast as Elector of Saxony.
Luther studied Erasmus's Greek New Testament (1516) and drew on humanist philological methods. The relationship broke over the free will controversy in 1524.
Zwingli was deeply influenced by Erasmus's biblical humanism and studied his Greek New Testament. They corresponded and may have met at Basel.
Patrick Hamilton studied at the University of Marburg and absorbed Lutheran theology, likely attending lectures by Melanchthon-influenced faculty.
Robert Barnes visited Wittenberg multiple times, became friends with Luther, and was influenced by Lutheran theology.
Calvin spent his Strasbourg exile (1538-1541) under Bucer's mentorship. Bucer influenced Calvin's ecclesiology and pastoral practice.
Olivétan studied Hebrew under Capito in Strasbourg, equipping him for his translation of the Old Testament into French.
Thomas Bilney converted Hugh Latimer to evangelical views at Cambridge, reportedly by asking Latimer to hear his confession.
John Knox served as George Wishart's bodyguard and disciple in 1545-1546. Wishart's execution was formative for Knox's career.
Hamilton's martyrdom (1528) inspired subsequent Scottish reformers including Wishart. His 'Patrick's Places' circulated as a summary of Protestant doctrine.
Knox spent time in Geneva and was profoundly influenced by Calvin's Reformed theology and church organization. Knox called Geneva 'the most perfect school of Christ.'
Heinrich Bullinger succeeded Zwingli as Antistes of Zurich after Zwingli's death at the Battle of Kappel (October 11, 1531).
Theodore Beza succeeded Calvin as moderator of the Company of Pastors in Geneva after Calvin's death (May 27, 1564).
Rudolf Gwalther succeeded Bullinger as Antistes of Zurich upon Bullinger's death in 1575.
John the Steadfast succeeded his brother Frederick the Wise as Elector of Saxony in 1525.
John Frederick I succeeded his father John the Steadfast as Elector of Saxony in 1532.
Luther and Melanchthon were the two central figures of Wittenberg theology for nearly 30 years. Melanchthon systematized Lutheran theology and drafted the Augsburg Confession.
Bugenhagen was Luther's pastor and confessor. He married Luther and Katharina, baptized their children, and preached Luther's funeral sermon.
Justus Jonas translated Luther's and Melanchthon's Latin works into German. He was present at Luther's death in Eisleben (1546).
Spalatin was the crucial intermediary between Luther and Elector Frederick the Wise, explaining Luther's theology to the elector and helping secure Luther's protection.
Lucas Cranach the Elder was Luther's close friend and collaborator. He created the visual imagery of the Reformation through portraits, woodcuts, and altarpieces.
Melanchthon and Bugenhagen were colleagues at Wittenberg, both part of the inner circle around Luther.
Cruciger was a Wittenberg faculty member who collaborated with Melanchthon and Luther on the Bible translation.
Leo Jud and Zwingli were close friends from their student days. Jud came to Zurich in 1522 and collaborated closely with Zwingli on the Reformation.
Zwingli and Oecolampadius were allies on the symbolic understanding of the Eucharist against Luther. They worked together at the Marburg Colloquy (1529).
After Zwingli's death, Bullinger and Leo Jud continued to lead the Zurich Reformation together until Jud's death in 1542.
Megander was a defender of Zwinglian theology who worked with Bullinger in defending the Swiss Reformed position.
Farel persuaded Calvin to stay in Geneva in 1536. They were expelled together in 1538 and Calvin returned in 1541. They remained colleagues throughout.
Pierre Viret was Calvin's close colleague, working with him and Farel in early Geneva. Part of the 'triumvirate' of Geneva's reform.
Beza joined Calvin in Geneva and became rector of the Geneva Academy (1559). He was Calvin's closest associate in his final years.
Farel and Viret worked together in the French-speaking Swiss Reformation, part of the 'triumvirate' with Calvin.
Froment worked alongside Farel in introducing the Reformation to Geneva in the early 1530s.
Bucer and Capito were the two leading reformers in Strasbourg. They co-authored the Tetrapolitan Confession (1530).
Matthew Zell was one of the first Strasbourg priests to preach Protestant ideas. Bucer joined him in leading the Strasbourg Reformation.
Katharina Schütz Zell was an active participant in the Strasbourg reform circle.
Nicholas Ridley served as Cranmer's chaplain and collaborated closely with him on liturgical and doctrinal reform. They were martyred together.
Latimer was one of Cranmer's colleagues in the English Reformation. Both were Oxford Martyrs.
Cranmer and Cromwell were the two chief architects of Henry VIII's religious and political reformation.
Ridley and Latimer were fellow reformers under Edward VI and were burned at the stake together at Oxford on October 16, 1555.
John Frith was Tyndale's associate and assistant in exile. Frith was burned at Smithfield in 1533.
Coverdale worked with Tyndale on Bible translation and used Tyndale's work extensively in producing the first complete printed English Bible (1535).
Cromwell patronized and protected Coverdale's Bible translation work, securing royal license for the Great Bible (1539).
Bucer came to England in 1549 at Cranmer's invitation. He was appointed Regius Professor at Cambridge and influenced the 1552 Book of Common Prayer through his Censura.
Conrad Grebel and Felix Manz were co-founders of the Swiss Brethren (Anabaptists). They performed the first adult rebaptism on January 21, 1525.
George Blaurock was baptized by Grebel at the founding of the Swiss Brethren (January 21, 1525) and became a missionary for the movement.
Manz and Blaurock were fellow Anabaptist leaders in the early Swiss Brethren movement, arrested and released together multiple times.
Erasmus and More were close friends from 1499. Erasmus wrote The Praise of Folly (1509) at More's home. Their correspondence lasted decades.
Erasmus met Colet at Oxford in 1499. Colet's lectures on Paul inspired Erasmus to pursue biblical scholarship.
More and Colet were part of the same English humanist circle with Erasmus.
Lefèvre d'Étaples was part of Bishop Briçonnet's reform circle at Meaux, attempting evangelical reform within the Catholic Church.
Farel was initially part of Lefèvre's Meaux Circle before moving toward more radical reform.
Marguerite protected Lefèvre and other reformers, using her influence as sister of King Francis I. Lefèvre spent his final years at her court.
Marot was a court poet under Marguerite's patronage. She protected him when his Protestant sympathies brought danger.
Erasmus and Reuchlin corresponded as fellow humanist scholars. Erasmus supported Reuchlin during the 'Reuchlin Affair' controversy.
Capito and Erasmus met at Basel and corresponded. They later became estranged as Capito moved toward Protestant reform.
Spalatin corresponded with Erasmus and other humanists as part of his role at the Saxon court.
Calvin and Melanchthon maintained a friendly correspondence despite Lutheran-Reformed tensions. They addressed each other warmly and sought common ground.
Bullinger and Calvin corresponded extensively and reached agreement in the Consensus Tigurinus (1549) on the Eucharist.
Bullinger corresponded with Cranmer and influenced the English Reformation. Many English exiles under Mary I fled to Zurich.
Hooper lived in Zurich during his exile (1547-1549) and was influenced by Bullinger's more radical Reformed views.
Knox and Beza corresponded during Knox's Geneva exile and afterward as Knox led the Scottish Reformation.
Frederick the Wise protected Luther from papal and imperial action. He arranged Luther's 'kidnapping' to Wartburg Castle for his safety.
Spalatin served Frederick the Wise as secretary, chaplain, and court historian.
Lucas Cranach the Elder was court painter to Frederick the Wise and his successors.
John the Steadfast continued his brother's protection of Luther and openly embraced Lutheranism.
John Frederick I continued Saxon patronage of Luther and the Reformation, leading the Schmalkaldic League.
Philip of Hesse was one of the most active Protestant princes, co-founding the Schmalkaldic League with Saxony.
Henry VIII appointed Cranmer Archbishop of Canterbury (1533) and relied on him to annul his marriage to Catherine of Aragon.
Henry VIII relied on Thomas Cromwell as chief minister to engineer the break with Rome and dissolve the monasteries.
Cromwell patronized Barnes and used him as a diplomatic intermediary with Lutheran Germany.
Cromwell supported Coverdale's Bible translation work and secured official approval for the Great Bible (1539).
The Luther-Erasmus controversy over free will (1524-1525) was one of the defining intellectual battles of the Reformation.
Luther and Zwingli disagreed fundamentally on the Lord's Supper. At the Marburg Colloquy (1529), they could not reconcile on the Eucharist.
Karlstadt was initially Luther's colleague but led radical reforms during Luther's Wartburg exile. Luther returned to reverse Karlstadt's changes.
Luther rejected Müntzer's emphasis on direct revelation and social revolution, calling him a 'murderous prophet.'
Johann Eck was Luther's chief Catholic opponent. At the Leipzig Debate (1519), Eck maneuvered Luther into admitting sympathy with Hus.
Cardinal Cajetan interrogated Luther at Augsburg (October 1518) on behalf of the pope, demanding recantation. Luther refused.
Grebel was Zwingli's student who broke with him over infant baptism and the pace of reform.
Felix Manz was executed by the Zurich council (with Zwingli's approval) by drowning on January 5, 1527—the first Swiss Anabaptist martyr.
The Antinomian Controversy pitted Luther against his former student Agricola over the role of the law in Christian life.
Thomas More wrote polemics against Luther under a pseudonym (Responsio ad Lutherum, 1523) defending Catholic doctrine and papal authority.
More wrote multiple polemical works against Tyndale's Bible translation and theology, including the massive Confutation of Tyndale's Answer.
Erasmus became estranged from Oecolampadius when Basel adopted the Reformation (1529). Erasmus left Basel for Freiburg.
Hooper initially refused consecration as bishop because he objected to wearing vestments. Cranmer insisted on traditional vestments.
Tyndale's English New Testament (1526) was significantly influenced by Luther's German translation. Tyndale may have studied in Wittenberg.
Bilney was converted to evangelical faith by reading Erasmus's Greek New Testament, specifically the Latin translation of 1 Timothy 1:15.
Lucas Cranach sheltered Katharina and other escaped nuns at his Wittenberg home in 1523 after their escape from the convent.
Johannes Bugenhagen performed the marriage ceremony of Luther and Katharina von Bora on June 13, 1525, and preached Luther's funeral sermon.
Calvin collaborated with Marot on the Genevan Psalter. Marot's metrical French translations of the Psalms became the foundation of Huguenot worship.
Bucer served as a theological adviser to Philip of Hesse and participated in the Marburg Colloquy (1529).
Philip organized and hosted the Marburg Colloquy (October 1529), inviting both Luther and Zwingli to attempt to reconcile their differences.
Charles V presided over the Diet of Worms (1521) where Luther was condemned. He spent decades trying to suppress Protestantism.
Justus Jonas was present at Luther's death in Eisleben on February 18, 1546, and recorded his final moments.
John Foxe chronicled the martyrdoms of Cranmer, Ridley, and Latimer in his Actes and Monuments (1563).
Luther's academic disputation challenging indulgences, posted October 31, 1517
First of Luther's 1520 Reformation treatises; 4,000 copies sold in first week
Luther's most radical theological work of 1520, attacking sacramental system
Luther's clearest statement of justification by faith alone (November 1520)
Luther's response to Erasmus; he later called it one of his best works
Luther's instruction for ordinary Christians (1529)
Extended catechetical instruction for pastors (1529)
Luther wrote ~37 hymns establishing German Protestant hymnody
Translated NT at Wartburg in 11 weeks; led Bible translation committee
Thousands of letters documenting Luther's relationships and Reformation spread
Assisted Luther with Greek; member of Wittenberg translation circle
Member of Wittenberg Bible translation committee
Member of Wittenberg Bible translation committee
Collaborated with Luther on Bible translation
Erasmus's critique of Luther on human will (September 1524)
First published Greek NT, enabling vernacular translations
Written at Thomas More's home; satirical critique of church corruption
Erasmus's program for lay Christian life (1503)
Over 3,000 letters documenting humanist network
Definitive Reformed theological work; grew from 6 to 80 chapters
Calvin's catechism for Genevan church (1542)
Platform for First Zurich Disputation (January 1523)
Zwingli's most comprehensive theological work (1525)
Supervised Zurich Bible translation until his death (1531)
Primary translator of Zurich Bible; led project after Zwingli's death
First systematic Lutheran theology; Luther called it worthy of canon
Primary confession of Lutheran churches, presented June 25, 1530
Defense and expansion of Augsburg Confession (1531)
First printed English NT from Greek; ~80% appears in KJV
First printed English OT books from Hebrew (1530)
Argument for royal supremacy; reportedly shown to Henry VIII by Anne Boleyn
First complete printed English Bible (1535)
First officially authorized English Bible; Coverdale edited
First vernacular prayer book for Church of England (1549)
Revised prayer book with more Protestant theology (1552)
Reformed liturgy that influenced Calvin and Cranmer
Co-authored confession of four South German cities at Augsburg (1530)
Co-authored Tetrapolitan Confession with Bucer
First French Bible from original languages; commissioned by Waldensians
First common confession of Swiss Reformed churches (1536)
Co-authored First Helvetic Confession with Bullinger
Most widely adopted Reformed confession of 16th century (1566)
~12,000 letters documenting Reformed network across Europe
Foundational Anabaptist statement; Sattler executed three months later
Foundational confession of Church of Scotland (1560)
Argument against female rulers; angered Elizabeth I
Based on Cranmer's Forty-Two Articles, finalized 1563
Comprehensive martyrology shaping English Protestant identity
Marot translated 49 Psalms in French verse
Beza completed the remaining Psalms after Marot's death

Luther died February 18, 1546 while visiting Eisleben

Luther's base 1511-1546; taught at university

Luther's pastor at Wittenberg; died there 1558
